holdings.text: High Court jurisdiction under Art. 226 to issue certiorari against Commissioner's s.51 order exists despite statutory finality, but limited to error of law apparent on face of record.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls to be considered is what are the limits of the High Courts jurisdiction in issuing a writ of certiorari in respect of orders like the one pronounced by the Commissioner in the present case? Mr. Venugopal contends that

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.51 finality does not oust constitutional jurisdiction; follows precedents distinguishing jurisdictional facts from merits, allowing certiorari for apparent legal errors per Nagendra Nath, Syed Yakoob.

holdings.text: Appellant is not an 'employer' under s.2(5) as he did not have general management or control of the establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention was that the appellant is not an employee of the respondent and does not fall under s. 2(12) which defines a person employed for the simple reason that he comes under the class of persons

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(5) requires overall control of establishment, not departmental; no evidence appellant had such; plea frivolous and not raised earlier.

holdings.text: A person is employed in 'position of management' under s.4(1)(a) if having powers like operating bank accounts, entering contracts, supervising staff, granting leave, disciplining, appointing, etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multi-factor test derived from practical considerations beyond salary; Commissioner correctly applied these tests to facts and evidence, finding appellant lacked such powers.

holdings.text: Commissioner of Labour correctly held appellant not in position of management under s.4(1)(a); no exemption from Act.

holdings.text: In writ proceedings, if error apparent on record found, High Court should quash and remit to tribunal rather than substitute own findings on evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Usual course in certiorari is correction and remand; inappropriate for High Court to decide merits left to special tribunal.

precedents.citation: Rai Brij Raj Krishana and another S.K. Shaw Brothers 1

anchor.surface_text: Rai Brij Raj Krishana and another S.K. Shaw Brothers 1 . In that case, this Court was dealing with the scheme of the Bihar Buildings  Lease, Rent and Eviction  Control Act  No. 111 of 1947  and the provisions of S. 11 in particular. Fazl Ali J. who spoke for the Court observed that the Act has set up a companyplete machinery for the investigation of the matters mentioned in it upon which the jurisdiction of the Controller to order eviction of a tenant depends, and it expressly  1  1951 S.C.R. 145.

precedents.case_name: Rai Brij Raj Krishana and another S.K. Shaw Brothers
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between collateral facts conferring jurisdiction and facts decided on merits by tribunal; finality of tribunal decision on merits cannot be questioned in court even if erroneous
precedents.cited_holding: even if the Controller may be assumed to have wrongly decided the question of non-payment of rent, his order cannot be questioned in a civil court

precedents.citation: Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan 1

anchor.surface_text: Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan 1 . Sir James Colville had observed in that case that the authorities establish that an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if numberdefect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will number on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found.

precedents.case_name: Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan
precedents.cited_proposition: Certiorari does not lie to quash an adjudication on erroneous finding of fact if no defect on face and tribunal had jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will not on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found

precedents.citation: Parry Co. Ltd. vs. Commercial Employees Association, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Parry Co. Ltd. vs. Commercial Employees Association, Madras 1 . In that case, Mukherjee J. stated that no certiorari is available to quash a decision passed with jurisdiction by an inferior tribunal on the mere ground that such decision is erroneous, and be has further added that it was conceded by Mr. Isaacs that in spite of the relevant statutory provisions the superior Court is not absolutely deprived of the power to issue a writ, although it can do so only on the ground of either a manifest defect of jurisdiction in the tribunal that made the order or of a manifest fraud in the party procuring it.

precedents.case_name: Parry Co. Ltd. vs. Commercial Employees Association, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Certiorari not available for erroneous decision if tribunal had jurisdiction, only for lack of jurisdiction or fraud
precedents.cited_holding: no certiorari is available to quash a decision passed with jurisdiction by an inferior tribunal on the mere ground that such decision is erroneous

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath v. Commissioner of Hills Division. 2

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra Nath v. Commissioner of Hills Division. 2 , it is clear from an examination of the authorities of this Court as also of the Courts in England, that one of the grounds on which the jurisdiction of the High Court on certiorari may be invoked, is an error of law apparent on the face of the record and not every error either of law or fact, which can be corrected by a superior Court, in exercise of its statutory powers as a Court of appeal of revision.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath v. Commissioner of Hills Division
precedents.cited_proposition: Certiorari lies for error of law apparent on the face of the record
precedents.cited_holding: one of the grounds on which the jurisdiction of the High Court on certiorari may be invoked, is an error of law apparent on the face of the record and not every error either of law or fact

precedents.citation: Syed Yakoob v. K.S. Radhakrishnan Ors. 1

precedents.case_name: Syed Yakoob v. K.S. Radhakrishnan Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: It is difficult to lay down general test for error of law apparent on face of record
